The bowells of the earth, my stepmother,
And not a naturall parent? or thus practise
To dye, and as I were insensible,
Believe I had no motion lies on his face Enter Gonzaga Adorn. Iaylor.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: There he is:
Ile not enquire by whom his ransome's pai'd
I am satisfi'd that I have it: nor alleage
One reason to excuse his cruell usage,
As you may interpret it, let it suffice
It was my will to have it so, he is yours now,
Dispose of him as you please Exit Gonzaga.

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: How e'r I hate him,
As one preferr'd before me, being a man,
He does deserve my pitty. Sir, he sleepes:
Or is he dead? would hee were a Saint in heaven;
'Tis is all the hurt I wish him. But was not Kneeles by him.
Borne o such happinesse. No he breaths, come neer,
And if 't be possible, without his feeling
Take off his yrons so, now leave us privat His yrons taken off.
He does begin to stir, and as transported Exit Jaylor.
With a joyfull dreame, how he stares! and feeles his legges,
As yet uncertaine, whether it can be
True or phantasticall.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ministers of mercy
Mocke not calamitie. Ha! 'tis no vision!
Or if it be, the happiest that ever
Appear'd to sinfull flesh! who's here! His face
Speakes him Adorni! but some glorious Angell
Concealing its divinity in his shape,
Hath done this miracle, it being not an act
For wolvish man. Resolve me, if thou look'st for
Bent knees in adoration?

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: O forbeare Sir,
I am Adorni, and the instrument
Of your deliverance; but the benefit
You owe another.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: If he has a name,
Assoone as spoken, 'tis writ on my heart,
I am his bondsman.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: To the shame of men,
This great act is a womans.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: The whole sex
For her sake must be deifi'd. How I wander
In my imagination, yet cannot
Ghesse who this Phoenix should be!

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: 'Tis Camiola.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Pray you speake't againe, there's musicke in her name
Once more I pray you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Camiola,
The Maid of honor,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Curs'd Atheist that I was,
Onely to doubt it could be any other,
Since she alone in the abstract of her selfe,
That small, but ravishing substance comprehends
What ever is, or can be wished, in the
Iudea of a woman. O what service,
Or sacrifice of duty can I pay her!
If not to live, and dye her charities slave,
Which is resolv'd already.

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: She expects not
Such a dominion ore you: yet ere I
Deliver her demands, give me your hand:
On this, as she enjoyn'd me, with my lips
I print her love and service by me sent you,

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I am orewhelm'd with wonder!

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: You must now
(Which is the sum of all that she desires)
By a solemne contract bind your selfe, when she
Requires it as a debt, due for your fredome
To marrie her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: This does ingage me further,
A payment! an increase of obligation!
To marry her! 'twas my nil ultra ever!
The end of my ambition! O that now
The holy man, she present, were prepar'd
To joyne our hands, but with that speed, my heart
Wishes, mine eyes might see her.

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: You must sweare this.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Swear it? Collect all oaths, and imprecations
Whose least breach is damnation, and those
Ministred to me in a forme more dreadfull,
Set heaven, and hell before me, I will take 'em:
False to Camiola? Never. Shall I now
Begin my vowes to you?

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: I am no Church-man,
Such a one must file it on record, you are free,
And that you may appeare like to your selfe
(For so she wish'd) her's gold with which you may
Redeeme your truncks and servants, and what ever
Of late you lost. I have found out the Captaine
Whose spoyle they were. His name is Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I know him.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: I have done my parts.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: So much Sir
As I am ever your's for't, now me thinkes
I walke in ayre! divine Camiola,
But words cannot expresse thee. I'll build to thee
An altar in my soule, on which I'll offer
A still increasing sacrifice of duty. Exit Ber.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: What will become of me now is apparant!
Whether a poniard, or a halter be
The nearest way to hell (for I must thither,
After I have kill'd my selfe) is somewhat doubtfull?
This Roman resolution of selfe-murther,
Will not hold water, at the high Tribunall,
When it comes to be argu'd; my good Genius
Prompts me to this consideration. He
That kills himselfe, to avoid misery, feares it,
And at the best shewes but a bastard valour,
This lifes a fort committed to my trust,
Which I must not yeeld up, till it be forc'd,
Nor will I: Hee's not valiant that dares dy,
But he that boldly beares calamitie.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCENE. IV. A Flourish.
div.stage: Pierio. Roderigo. Iacomo. Gonzaga. Aurelia. Ferdinand. Astutio. Attendants.

sp.speaker: Aurelia.
sp.l: A Seat here for the Duke. It is our glory
To overcom with courtesies, not rigor;
To Lordly Roman, who held it the height
Of humane happinesse, to have kings and Queenes
To wait by his triumphant chariot wheeles
In his insulting pride, depriv'd himselfe
Of drawing neare the nature of the gods,
Best known for such, in being mercifull,
Yet give me leave, but still with gentle language,
And with the freedome of a friend to tell you,
To seeke by force, what courtship could not win,
was not harsh, and never taught in loves milde schoole.
Wise Poets faine that Venus coach is draw'n
By doues, and sparrowes, not by beares, and tygres.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I spare the application.
In my fortune,
Heav'ns justice hath confirm'd it, yet great Lady,
Since my offence grew from excesse of love,
And not to be resisted, having paid too,
With the losse of liberty, the forfeyture
Of my presumption, in your clemency
It may finde pardon

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You shall have just cause
To say it hath. The charge of the long siege
Defraid, and the losse my subjects have sustain'd
Made good, since so farre I must deale with caution,
You have your liberty

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I could not hope for gentler conditions.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: My Lord Gonzaga.
Since my comming to Siena, I haue heard much
Of your prisoner; brave Bertoldo.

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: Such an one, Madam, I had.

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: And have still, Sir, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Your hopes deceive you. He is ransom'd Madame,

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: By whom, I pray you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gonzag.
sp.l: You had best enquire
Of your intelligencer. I am no informer.

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: I like not this.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: He is, as 'tis reported,
A goodly gentleman, and of noble parts,
A brother of your order.

sp.speaker: Gonzaga.
sp.l: Hee was, Madam,
Till he against his oath wrong'd you, a princesse,
Which his religion bound him from.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Great mindes
For tryall of their valours oft maintaine
Quarrells that are unjust, yet without malice,
And such a faire construction I make of him.
I would see that brave enemy;

sp.speaker: Gonzaga.
sp.l: My duty
Commands me to seeke for him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Pray you doe:
And bring him to our presence. Exit Gonzaga.

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: I must blast
His entertainment; may it please your excellency,
He is a man debauch'd, and for his riots
Cast off by the King my Master, and that, I hope, is
A crime sufficient

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: To you his subjects,
That like as your king likes Enter Gonzaga, Bertoldo, richly habited: Adorni.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: But not to us;
We must waigh with our owne scale. This is he, sure!
How soone mine eye had found him! what a port
He beares! how well his bravery becomes him!
A prisoner! nay, a princly sutor rather!
But I am too sudden.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Madame, 'twas his suite,
Vnsent for, to present his service to you,
Ere his departure.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: With what Majesty
He beares himselfe!

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: The divell I thinke supplies him,
Ransom'd, and thus rich too!

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You ill deserve Ferdinand kneeling, kisses her hand.
The favour of our hand; we are not well,
Give us more ayre. She descends suddenly

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: What sudden qualme is this?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: That lifted yours against mee.

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: Thus once more,
I sue for pardon

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sure his lips are poyson'd,
And through those veines, force passage to my heart Aside.
Which is already seaz'd upon.

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: I wait, Madam,
To know what your commands are; my designes
Exact me in another place.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Before
You have our licence to depart; if manners,
Civility of manners cannot teach you
T'attend our leasure, I must tell you, Sir,
That you are still our prisoner, nor had you
Commission to free him.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: How's this, Madam?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You were my substitute, and wanted power
Without my warrant to dispose of him.
I will pay backe his ransome ten times over,
Rather then quit my interest.

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: This is
Against the law of armes.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: But not of love: Aside.
Why, hath your entertainment, Sir, beene such
In your restraint, that with the wings of feare
You would flie from it?

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: I know no man, Madame,
Enamour'd of his fetters, or delighting
In cold or hunger, or that would in reason
Preferre straw in a dungeon, before
A downe bed in a Palace.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: How, come neerer;
Was his usage such?

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Yes, and it had beene worse,
Had I foreseene this.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O thou mis-shap'd monster!
In thee it is confirm'd, that such as have
No share in natures bounties, know no pitty
To such as have 'em Looke on him with my eyes,
And answer then, whether this were a man,
Whose cheekes of lovely fulnesse should be made
A prey to meagre famine? or these eyes
Whose every glance store Cupids empti'd quiver,
To be dimm'd with tedious watching? or these lips,
These rudie lips, of whose fresh colour, cherries
And roses were but coppies, should grow pale
For want of Nectar? or these legges that beare
A burthen of more worth, then is supported
By Atlas wearied shoulders, should be cramp'd
With the weight of yron? O I could dwell ever
On this description!

sp.speaker: Bertoldo.
sp.l: Is this in dirision
Or pitty of me?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: In your charity
Beleeve me innocent. Now you are my prisoner
You shall have fairer quarter, you will shame
The place where you have beene, should you now leave it
Before you are recover'd. I'll conduct you
To more convenient lodgings, and it shall be
My care to cherish you. Repine who dare;
It is our will. You'll follow mee?

sp.speaker: Bertoldo.
sp.l: To the centre,
Such a Sybilla guiding me. Exeunt Aurelia, Bertoldo

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Who speakes first?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: We stand, as we had seen Medusas head! All amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Pierio.
sp.l: I know not what to thinke, I am so amaz'd!

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Amaz'd! I am thunderstrooke!

sp.speaker: Iacom.
sp.l: Wee are inchaunted,
And this is some illusion.

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: Heav'n forbid!
In darke despaire, it shewes a beame of hope.
Containe thy joy, Adorni.

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: Such a Princesse,
And of so long experienc'd reservednesse
Breake forth, and on the sudden, into flashes
Of more then doubted loosenesse.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: They come againe,
Smiling, as I live: His arme circling her wast:
I shall runne mad: Some fury hath possess'd her.
If I speake, I may be blasted. Ha, I'll mumble
A prayer or two, and crosse my selfe, and then
Though the divell fart fire, have at him.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Let not, Sir,
The violence of my passions nourish in you
An ill opinion; or grant my carriage
Out of the rode, and garbe of private women,
'Tis still done with decorum. As I am
A Princesse, what I doe, is aboue censure,
And to be imitated.

sp.speaker: Bertoldo.
sp.l: Gracious Madam,
Vouchsafe a little pawse, for I am so rapt
Beyond my selfe, that 'till I have collected
My scatter'd faculties, I cannot tender
My resolution.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Consider of it,
I will not be long from you, Bertoldo walking by musing.

sp.speaker: Gonzaga.
sp.l: Pray I cannot!
This cursed object strangles my devotion!
I must speake, or I burst. Pray you faire Lady,
If you can in courtesie, direct mee to
The chaste Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Are you blinde? who are wee?

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: Another kind of thing. Her blood was govern'd
By her discretion, and not rul'd her reason
The reverence and Majesty of Iuno
Shinde in her lookes, and comming to the campe,
Appear'd a second Pallas. I can see
No such divinities in you. If I
Without offence may speake my thoughts, you are,
As it were, a wanton Helen.

sp.speaker: Aurelia.
sp.l: Good, ere long
You shall know mee better.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Why, if you are Aurelias
How shall I dispose of the Souldier?

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: May it please you
To hasten my dispatch?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Prefer your suites
Vnto Bertoldo, we will give him hearing,
And you'll finde him your best advocate. Exit Aurelia

sp.speaker: Astut.
sp.l: This is rare!

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: What are we come to?

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Grown up in a moment
A favorite!

sp.speaker: Ferdi.
sp.l: He does take state already.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: No, no, it cannot be, yet but Camiola,
There is no stop betweene me and a crowne,
Then my ingratitude! a sinne in which
All sinnes are comprehended! Aide me vertue,
Or I am lost.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: May it please your excellence
Second me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Then my so horrid oathes,
And hell. deepe imprecations made against it.

sp.speaker: Astu.
sp.l: The king your brother will thank you for thadvācment
Of his affaires

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: And yet who can hold out
Against such batteries, as her power and greatnesse
Raise up against my weake defences!

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Sir, Enter Aurelia.
Doe you dreame waking, Slight, shee's here againe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Walkes she on woollen feete!

sp.speaker: Aureli.
sp.l: You dwell too long
In your deliberation, and come
With a criples pace to that which you should fly to

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: It is confess'd, yet why should I to winne
From you, that hazzard all to my poore nothing,
By false play send you off a looser from me?
I'am already too too much ingag'd
To the king my brothers anger; and who knowes
But that his doubts, and politick feares, should you
Make me his equall, may draw war upon
Your territories, were that breach made up
I should with joy embrace, what now I feare
To touch but with due reverence.

sp.speaker: Aureli.
sp.l: That hinderance
Is easily remov'd. I owe the king
For a royall visit which I straight will pay him,
And having first reconcil'd you to his favour,
A dispensation shall meete with us,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am wholly yours.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: On this booke seale it.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: What hand and lip too, then the bargayne's sure,
You have no imployment for me?

sp.speaker: Aureli
sp.l: Yes Gonzaga,
Provide a royall ship.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: A ship? Saint Iohn,
Whither are we bound now?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You shall know hereafter,
My lord your pardon, for my too much trenching upon your patience.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Camiola. Whispers to Bertoldo

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: How doe you

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Indisposed, but I attend you. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: The heavie curse that waites on perjurie,
And foule ingratitude, pursue thee ever.
Yet why from me this? In this breach of faith
My loyalty findes reward! what poysons him
Proves Mithridate to me! I have perform'd
All she commanded punctually, and now
In the cleare mirrour of my truth, she may
Behold his falsehood. O that I had wings
To beare me to Palermo! This once knowne,
Must change her love into a just disdaine,
And worke her to compassion of my paine.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCENE. V.
div.stage: Sylli. Camiola. Clarinda. At severall doores.

sp.speaker: Sylli.
sp.l: Vndone! vndone! poore I that whilome was
The top and ridge of my house, am on the sudden
Turn'd to the pittifullest animal
Of the lignage of the Syllies!

sp.speaker: Cami.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: The king! breake gyrdle, breake!

sp.speaker: Cami.
sp.l: Why? what of him?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Hearing how far you doted on my person,
Growing envious of my happines, and knowing
His brother, nor his favorite Fulgentio,
Could get a sheepes eie from you, I being present,
Is come himselfe a suitor, with the awle
Of his authoritie to bore my nose,
And take you from me, Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do not rore so;
The king!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: The king! yet loving Sylli is not
So sorrie for his owne, as your misfortune,
If the king should carrie you, or you beare him,
What a looser should you be? He can but make you
A queene, and what a simple thing is that
To the being my lawful spouse. The world can never
Affoord you such a husband.

sp.speaker: Cami.
sp.l: I beleeve you,
But how are you sure the king is so inclin'd?
Did not you dreame this?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: With these eyes I saw him
Dismisse his traine, and lightning from his coach,
Whispering Fulgentio in the eare.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: If so
I ghesse the businesse

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: It can be no other
But to give me the bob, that being a matter
Of maine importance, yonder they are, I dare not
Be seene, I am so desperate, if you forsake me, Exit Rob. Ful.
Send me word that I may provide a willow ghyrlond
To weare when I drowne my selfe. O Sylli, ô Sylli! Exit crying

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: It will be worth your paines Sir to observe
The constancie and brauery of her spirit,
Though great men tremble at your frownes, I dare
Hazzard my head, your majesty set off
With terror, cannot fright her.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: May she answer
My expectation.

sp.speaker: Fulgen.
sp.l: There she is.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My knees thus
Bent to the earth (while my vowes are sent upward
For the safety of my Soveraigne) pay the duty
Due for so great an honor, in this favour
Done to your humblest hand-maid.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.l: You mistake me,
I come not (Lady) that you may report,
The king to do you honor, made your house
(He being there) his court, but to correct
Your stubborne disobedience. A pardon
For that, could you obtaine it, were well purchas'd
With this humility.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: A pardon Sir?
'Till I am conscious of an offence.
I will not wrong my innocence to begge one,
What is my crime Sir?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Look on him I favour,
By you scorn'd and negelected.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Is that all Sr.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: No minion, though that were too much. How can you
Answer the setting on your desperate brauo
To murther him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: With your leave, I must not kneele Sir.
While I replie to this: But thus rise up
In my defence, and tell you as a man
(since when you are unjust, the diety
Which you may challenge as a King, parts from you
'Twas never read in holy writ, or morrall,
That subjects on their loyalty were oblig'd
To love their Soveraignes vices, your grace, Sir,
To such an undeserver is no vertue.

sp.speaker: Fulgen.
sp.l: What thinke you now Sir?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Say you should love wine,
You being the King, and cause I am your subject,
Must I beever drunke? Tyrants, not Kings
By violence, from humble vassails force
The liberty of their soules. I could not love him
And to compell affection, as I take it,
Is not found in your prerogative.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Excellent virgin!
How I admire her confidence

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He complaines
Of wrong done him: but he no more a King,
Vnlesse you do me right. Burne your decrees,
And of your lawes and statutes make a fire
To thawe frozen numnesse of delinquents,
If he escape unpunish'd. Doe your edicts
Call it death in any man that breakes into
Anothers house to rob him, though of trifles
And shall Fulgentio your Fulgentio live?
Who hath committed more then sacriledge
In the pollution of my cleare fame
By his malicious slanders

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Have you done this?
Answer truely on your life.

sp.speaker: Fulgen.
sp.l: In the heat of blood
Some such thing I reported.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Out of my sight,
For I vow, if by true penitence thou winne
This injur'd Lady to sue out thy pardon,
Thy grave is digg'd already.

sp.speaker: Fulgen.
sp.l: By my owne folly
I have made a faire hand of't, Exit Fulgen.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You shall know Lady
While I weare a crowne, justice shall use her sword
To cut offenders off, though neerest to us.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I, now you shew whose Deputy you are,
I now I bath your feet with teares, it cannot
Be censur'd superstition.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You must rise.
Rise in our favour, and protection ever: Kisses her

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Happy are subjects when the prince is still
Guided by justice, not his passionate will. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The end of the fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: YOu see how tender I am of the quiet
And peace of your affection, and what great ones
I put off in your favour.

sp.speaker: Sylli.
sp.l: You doe wisely.
Exceeding wisely! and when I have said,
I thanke you for't, be happy.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And good reason,
In having such a blessing.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: When you have it,
Bat the baite is not yet ready. Stay the time,
While I triumph by my selfe, King, by your leave,
I have wip'd your royall nose, without a napkin,
You may cry willow, willow, for your brother,
I'll onely say goe by; for my fine favourite,
He may graze, where he please, his lips may water
Like a puppies ore a frumenty pot, while Sylli
Out of his two-leav'd cherry-stone dish drinkes Nectar
I cannot hold out any longer; heav'n forgive me,
'Tis not the first oath, I have broke, I must take
A little for a preparative. Offers to kisse & embrace her.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: By no meanes.
If you forsweare your selfe we shall not prosper.
I'll rather loose my longing.

sp.speaker: Sylli.
sp.l: Pretty soule!
How carefull it is of me! let me buffe yet
Thy little dainty foot for't: that I am sure
Is out of my oath.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Why, if thou canst dispense with't
So faire, I'll not be scrupulous; such a favour
My amorous shoomaker steales

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: O most rare leather! Kisses her shooe often
I doe begin at the lowest, but in time
I may grow higher.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Fie, you dwell too long there!
Rise, prethee rise Enter Clarinda hastily

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: O I am up already.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: How I abuse my houres! what newes with thee now?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Off with that gowne, 'tis mine, mine by your promise
Signior Ador. is return'd! now upon entrance;
Off with it, off with it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Be not so hasty,
When I goe to bed 'tis thine.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: You have my grant too;
But doe you heare Lady, though I give way to this,
You must hereafter aske my leave before
You part with things of moment.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Very good,
When I am yours, I will be govern'd.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Sweet obedience! Ent. Ador.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You are well return'd.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: I wish that the successe
Of my service had deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Lives Bertoldo?

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Yes, and return'd with safety.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis not then
In the power of fate to adde to, or take from
My perfit happinesse: and yet he should
Have made me his first visit. Ador. So I think too
But he

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Darst not appeare, I being present,
That's his excuse, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Speake, where is he?
With whom? who hath deserv'd more from him? or
Can be of equall merit? I in this
Doe not except the King.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Hee's at the Palace
With the Dutchesse of Siena. One coach brought 'em hither.
Without a third. Hee's very gracious with her,
You may conceive the rest.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My jealous feares
Make me to apprehend.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Pray you dismisse
Signior wisdome, and i'll make relation to you
Of the particulars.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Servant, I would have you
To haste unto the Court.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I will out-runne
A foote-man for your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There observe
The Dutchesse traine and entertainment.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Feare not,
I will discover all that is of waight
To the liveries of her Pages, and her footemen.
This is fit imployment for me. Exit Syl.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Gracious with
The Dutchesse! sure you said so?

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: I will use
All possible brevity to enforme you, Madam,
Of what was trusted to me, and discharg'd
With faith and loyall duty.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I beleeve it
You ransom'd him, and suppli'd his wants imagine
That is already spoken; and-what vowes
Of service he made to me is apparent;
His joy of me, and wonder too perspicuous;
Does not your story end so?

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Would the end
Had answered the beginning, in a word,
Ingratitude, and perjury at the height
Cannot expresse him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Take heed.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Truth is arm'd
And can defend it selfe. It must out, Madam.
I saw, the presence full, the amorous Dutchesse
Kisse and embrace him, on his part accepted
With equall ardor, and their willing hands
No sooner joyn'd, but a remove was publish'd,
And put in execution.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The proofes are
Too pregnant. O Bertoldo!

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: Hee's not worth
Your sorrow, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Tell mee, when you saw this
Did not you grieve as I do now to heare it?

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: His precipice from goodnesse raising mine,
And serving as a foyle to set my faith off,
I had little reason.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: In this you confesse
The divellish malice of your disposition.
As you were a man, you stood bound to lament it,
And not in flattery of false your hopes
To glory in it: when good men pursue
The path mark'd out by vertue, the bless'd Saints
With joy looke on it, and Seraphique Angels
Clap their celestiall wings in heavenly plaudits,
To be a scene of grace so well presented,
The fiends and men made up of envy mourning;
Where as now on the contray as far
As their divinity can partake of passion,
With me they weepe, beholding a faire Temple
Built in Bertoldo's loyalty turn'd to ashes
By the flames of his inconstancy, the damn'd
Rejoycing in the object: 'Tis not well
In you Adorni.

sp.speaker: Adorni.
sp.l: What a temper dwells
In this rare Virgin, can you pitty him
That hath shown none to you?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I must not be
Cruell by his example, you perhaps,
Except now I should seeke recovery
Of what I have lost by teares, and with bent knees
Begge his compassion. No; my towring vertue
From the assurance of my merit scornes
To stoope so low. I'll take a nobler course,
And confident in the justice of my cause,
The King his brother, and new Mistresse, judges,
Ravish him from her armes, you have the contract
In which he swore to marry her?

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: 'Tis here Madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He shal be then against his wil my husband,
And when I have him, I'll so use him, doubt not,
But that your honesty being unquestion'd,
This writing with your testimony cleares all.

sp.speaker: Ador.
sp.l: And buries me in the darke mists of error.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I'll presently to Court, pray you give order
For my caroch.

sp.speaker: Adorn.
sp.l: A cart for mee were fitter
To hurry me to the gallowes Exit Adorni

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O false men!
Inconstant! perjur'd! my good Angell helpe mee
In these my extremities! Enter Syll.

sp.speaker: Sylli.
sp.l: If you ever will see brave sight,
Lose it not now. Bertoldo, and the Dutchesse
Are presently to be married. There's such pompe
And preparation.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: If I marry, 'tis
This day or never.

sp.speaker: Sylli.
sp.l: Why with all my heart,
Though I break this, I'll keep the next oath I make
And then it is quit.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Follow mee to my Cabinet,
You know my confessor, Father Paulo?

sp.speaker: Syll.
sp.l: Yes. Shall he
Doe the feate for us?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I will give in writing
Directions to him, and attire my selfe
Like a Virgin-bride, and something I will doe
That shall deserve mens praise, and wonder too.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: And I to make all know, I am not shallow
Will have my points of Cutchineale and yellow. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT. V. SCENE. II.
div.stage: Astutio. Gonzaga. Roderigo. Iacomo. Pierio. Roberto. Bertoldo. Aurelia. Bishop. with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: HAd our division beene greater, Madam,
Your clemency, the wrong being done to you
In pardon of it, like the rod of concord
Must make a perfect union, once more
With a brotherly affection we receive you
Into our favour. Let it be your study
Hereafter to deserve this blessing, farre
Beyond your merit.

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: As the Princesse grace
To me is without limit, my endeavours
With all obsequiousnesse to serve her pleasures
Shall know no bounds, nor will I being made
Her husband, forget the duty that
I owe her as a servant.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: I expect not
But faire equality, since I well know
If that superiority be due
'Tis not to me, When you are made my consort
All the prerogatives of my high birth cancell'd
I'll practise the obedience of a wife,
And freely pay it. Queenes themselves, if they
Make choice of their inferiors, onely aiming
To feed their sensuall appetites, and to raigne
Over their husbands, in some kinde commit
Authoriz'd whoredome, nor will I be guilty
In my intent of such a crime.

sp.speaker: Gonza.
sp.l: This done,
As it is promis'd, Madam, may well stand for
A president to great women: but when once
The griping hunger of desire is cloyd,
(And the poore foole advanc'd, brought on his knee
Most of your Eagle breed, I'll not say all
(Ever excepting you) challenge againe,
What in hot blood they parted from.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You are ever.
An enemy of our sex, but you I hope Sir
Have better thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I dare not entertaine
An ill one of your goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: To my power
I will enable him to prevent all danger
Envy can raise against your choice. One word more
Touching the Articles. Enter Ful. Cam. Syl. Ador.

sp.speaker: Fulgen.
sp.l: In you alone
Lie all my hopes, you can or kill or save me,
But pitty in you, will become you better,
(Though I confesse in justice 'tis deni'd me)
Then too much rigor.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I will make your peace
As far as it lyes in me, but must first
Labour to right my selfe.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Or adde or alter
What you thinke fit. In him I have my all,
Heaven make me thankfull for him.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: On to the Temple

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Stay royall Sir, and as you are a King
Erect one here, in doing justice to
An injur'd mayd.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O I am blasted!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I have given som proofe, sweet Lady, of my promptnes
To doe you right, you need not therefore doubt me,
And rest assur'd, that this great worke dispatch'd,
You shall have audience and satisfaction
To all you can demand.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: To doe mee justice
Exacts your present care, and can admit
Of no delay. If e'r my cause be heard
In favour of your brother, you goe on Sir,
Your scepter cannot right mee. Hee's the man,
The guilty man, whom I accuse, and you
Stand bound in duty, as you are Supreame,
To be impartiall. Since you are a Iudge,
As a Delinquent, looke on him, and not
As on a brother; justice painted blinde
Inferres, her Ministers are oblig'd to heare
The cause and truth, the Iudge determine of it,
And not sway'd, or by favour, or affection,
By a false glosse, or wrested comment alter
The true intent, and letter of the law.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Nor will I Madam,

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: You seeme troubl'd, Sir,

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: His colour changes too.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The alteration
Growes from his guilt. The goodnesse of my cause
Begets such confidence in mee, that I bring
No hir'd tongue to plead for mee, that with gay
Rhetoricall flourishes may palliate
That, which stripp'd naked, will appeare deform'd.
I stand here, mine owne advocate; and my truth
Deliver'd in the plainest language, will
Make good it selfe, nor will I, if the King
Give suffrage to it, but admit of you,
My greatest enemy, and this stranger Prince,
To sit assistants with him.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: I ne'r wrong'd you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: In your knowledge of the injury, I believe it,
Nor will you in your justice, when you are
Acquainted with my interest in this man
Which I lay claime to.

sp.speaker: Roberto.
sp.l: Let us take our seats,
What is your title to him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: By this contract
Seal'd solemnely before a reveren'd man,
I challenge him for my husband.

sp.speaker: Sylli.
sp.l: Ha. was I
Sent for the Frier, for this? O Sylli! Sylli!
Some cordiall, or I faint.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: This writing is
Authenticall.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: But done in heat of blood,
(Charm'd by her flatteries, as no doubt he was)
To be dispens'd with.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: Adde this, if you please,
The distance and disparity betweene
Their births and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What can inocence hope for
When such as sit her judges, are corrupted!
Disparity of birth, or fortune urge you?
Or Syren charmes? or at his best in mee,
Wants to deserve him? Call some few daies backe,
And as he was, consider him, and you
Must grant him my inferiour. Imagine
You saw him now in fetters with his honour,
His liberty lost; with her blacke wings despaire
Circling his miseries, and his Gonzaga.
Trampling on his afflictions; the great summe
Propos'd for his redemption; the King
Forbidding payment of it; this neere kinsmen,
With his protesting followers, and friends,
Falling off from him; by the whole world forsaken;
Dead to all hope, and buried in the grave
Of his calamities, and then waigh duly
What she deserv'd (whose merits now are doubted)
That as his better Angell in her bounties
Appeard unto him, his great ransome pai'd,
His wants, and with a prodigall hand suppli'd,
Whether then being my manumised slave,
Hee ow'd not himselfe to mee?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: Is this true?

sp.speaker: Roberto.
sp.l: In his silence 'tis acknoledg'd

sp.speaker: Gonzag.
sp.l: If you want
A witnesse to this purpose, I'll depose it:

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: If I have dwelt too long on my deservings
To this unthankfull man, pray you pardon me,
The cause requir'd it. And though now I adde
A little in my painting to the life
His barbarous ingratitude, to deterre,
Others from imitation, let it meet with
A faire interpretation. This serpent,
Frozen to numnesse, was no sooner warm'd
In the bosome of my pitty, and compassion,
But in returne, he ruin'de his preserver
The prints the yrons had made in his flesh
Still ulcerous; but all that I had done
(My benefits in sand, or water written)
As they had never beene, no more remembred.
And on what ground; but his ambitious hopes
To gaine this Duchesse favour,

sp.speaker: Aurelia.
sp.l: Yes, the object,
Looke on it better (Lady) may excuse
The charge of his affection.

sp.speaker: Camiol.
sp.l: The object
In what? forgiue mee, modesty, if I say
You looke upon your forme in the false glasse
Of flattery, and selfe love, and that deceives you,
That you were a Duchesse, as I take it, was not
Character'd on your face, and that not seene,
For other feature, make all these that are
Experienc'd in women, judges of 'em,
And if they are not Parasites, they must grant
For beauty without art, though you storme at it,
I may take the righ hand file.

sp.speaker: Gonzaga.
sp.l: Well said i'faith;
I see faire women on no termes will yeeld
Priority in beauty.

sp.speaker: Camiol.
sp.l: Downe proud heart!
Why doe I rise up in defence of that,
Which, in my cherishing of it hath vndone mee.
No Madam, I recant, you are all beauty,
Goodnesse, and vertue, and poore I not worthy
As a soyle to set you off; enioy your conquest
But doe not tyranize. Yet as I am
In my lownesse from your height, you may looke on me,
And in your suffrage to me, make him know
That though to all men else I did appeare
The shame and scorne of women, hee stands bound
To hold me as her master-piece.

sp.speaker: Roberto.
sp.l: By my life
You have show'n your selfe of such an abject temper,
So poore, and low condition'd, as I grieve for
Your neerenesse to mee.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: I am chang'd in my
Opinion of you Lady, and professe
The vertues of your minde, an ample fortune
For an absolute Monarch.

sp.speaker: Gonzaga.
sp.l: Since you are resolv'd
To damne your selfe, in your forsaking of
Your noble order for a woman, doe it
For this. You may search through the world, and meet not
With such another Phoenix.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: On the sudden
I feele all fires of love quench'd in the water
Of compassion, make your peace; you have
My free consent; for here I doe disclaime
All interest in you: and to further your
Desires, faire Maid, compos'd of worth and honour,
The dispensation procur'd by mee,
Freeing Bertoldo from his vow, makes way
To your embraces.

sp.speaker: Bertol.
sp.l: Oh, how have I stray'd,
And wilfully, out of the noble tract
Mark'd mee by vertue! 'Till now, I was never
Truely a prisoner; to excuse my late
Captivity, I might alleage the malice
Of fortune; you that conquer'd me confessing
Courage in my defence was no way wanting
But now I have surrendred up my strengths
Into the power of vice, and on my forehead
Branded with mine owne hand in capitall letters
Disloyall, and Ingratefull, though barr'd from
Humane society, and hiss'd into
Some desert nere yet haunted with the curses
Of men and women, sitting as a judge
Vpon my guilty selfe, I must confesse
It justly falls upon me, and one teare
Shed in compassion of my suffrings more.
Then I can hope for.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: This compunction
For the wrong that you have done me, though you should
Fix here, and your true sorrow move no further,
Will in respect I lov'd once, make these eies
Two springs of sorrow for you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: In your pittie
My cruelty shewes more monstrous, yet I am not,
Though most ingratfull, grown to such a height
Of impudence, as in my wishes onely
To aske your pardon. If as now I fall
Prostrate before your feete, you will vouchsafe
To act your owne revenge, treading upon me
As a viper eating through the bowels of
Your benefits, to whom with libertie
I owe my being, 'twill take from the burthen
That now is insupportable.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pray you rise,
As I wish peace, and quiet to my soule
I do forgive you heartily, yet excuse me:
Though I deny my selfe a blessing that
By the favour of the Dutchesse seconded,
With your submission is offer'd to me
Let not the reason I alleage for't grieve you,
You have been false once. I have done. And if
When I am married (as this day I will be)
As a perfit signe of your attonement with me
You wish me joy, I will receive it for
Full satisfaction of all obligations
In which you stand bound to me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I will doe it,
And what's more, in despite of sorrow, live
To see my selfe vndone, beyond all hope
To be made up againe.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: My blood begins
To come to my heart againe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pray you Signior Syl.
Call in the holy Frier. Hee's prepar'd
For finishing the worke.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I knew I was
The man. Heaven make mee thankfull

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Astu.
sp.l: His Father was the banker of Palermo,
And this the heyre of his great wealth, his wisdome
Was not hereditarie.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Though you know me not,
Your Majesty owes me a round Sum, I have
A seele, or two to witnesse, yet if you please
To weare my colours, and dance at my wedding
I'll never sue you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And I'll grant your suite,

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Gracious Maddona, Noble, Generall,
Brave Captaines and my quondam rivalls wear 'em
Since I am confident you dare not harbour
A thought, but that way currant. Exit

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.l: For my part
I cannot ghesse the issue. Enter Syl. with

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Do your duty,
And with all speed you can, you may despatch us.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.l: Thus as a principal ornament to the Church
I sease her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: So young and so religious.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: She has forsooke the world.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: And Syllie too,
I shall run mad. Syl thrust off

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Hence with the foole, proceede Sir

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Looke on this maid of honor now
Truely honor'd in her vow
She payes to heaven, vaine delight
By day, or pleasure of, the night,
She no more thinkes of this faire haire
(Favours for great kings to weare)
Muw now be shorn. Her rich array
Chang'd into a homely gray.
The dainties with which she was fed
And her proud flesh pampered,
Must not be tasted, from the spring,
For wine cold water we will bring
And with fasting mortifie
The feasts of sensuality.
Her jewells, beads, and she must looke
Not in a glasse, but holy booke;
To teach her the nere erring way
To immortality. O may
She as she purposes to be
A Child new borne to piety,
Persever in in it, and good men
With Saints and Angels say Amen

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: This is the marriage! this the port! to which
My vowes must steere me, fill my spreading sayles
With the pure wind of your devotions for me,
That I may touch the secure haven, where
Eternall happinesse keepes her reside mee,
Temptations to frailty never entring.
I am dead to the world, and thus dispose
Of what I leave behind me, and dividing
My state into three parts, I thus bequeath it.
The first to the faire Nunnery, to which
I dedicate the last, and better part
Of my fraile life; a second portion
To pious uses; and the third to thee
Adorni, for thy true and faithfull service.
And ere I mistake last farwel with hope
To finde a grant, may suite to you is that
You would for my sake pardon this young man
And to his merits love him, and no further.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I thus confirme it. Gives his hand to Fulgen. to Bertoldo

sp.speaker: Cami.
sp.l: And as ere you hope
Like me to be made happy, I conjure you
To reassume your order; and in fighting
Bravely against the enemies of our faith
Redeeme your morgag'd honor.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I restore this The white crosse.
Once more brothers in armes,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I'll live and die so.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: To you my pious wishes. And to end
All differences, great Sir I beseech you
To be an arbitrator, and compound
The quarrell, long continuing betweene
The Duke and Dutchesse.

sp.speaker: Rober.
sp.l: I'll take it into
My speciall care.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am then at rest, now father Exeunt Paulo. & Camiola.
Conduct me where you please.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: She well deserves
Her name, the Maid of Honor! May she stand
To all posterity, a faire example,
For noble Maides to imitate. Since to live
In wealth and pleasure is common; but to part with
Such poyson'd baites is rare, there being nothing
Vpon this Stage of life to be commended,
Though well begun, till it be fully ended. Exeunt.
